It is perhaps appropriate that each
year, as the season changes, Hopkins
conducts its own legislative transition.
The Student Council elections generally drag on from run-off to run-off, with
all the dreariness of the last days of
winter.
This year is no exception, made
markedly more monotonous by the lack
of a race for Council president. Let us
not allow this phenomenon to lead us to
declare this year's elections unimportant, however. After all, this year's
vice-presidential campaign has shaped
up to be quite a heated race, with no less
than three candidates each qualified
within his own right, contending for the
position.
Why, you ask, would a vice-presidential race attract so many candidates, and
why should it attract such interest? The
vice-president is important not so much
for his individual contribution to Council's meaningful deliberations, for we
know these to be few and far between.
Rather, the position is significant for the
power it wields.
The Council vice-president is chairman of the Committee on Committees,
(let not its enigmatic moniker mislead
you) the body which appoints students
to some of the most influential
undergraduate positions on campus. Not

only are Spring Fair, MSE Symposium,
and Orientation chairs chosen by this
committee, but also some less visible
ones, including the chair of the Committee on Undergraduate Studies and
those of the HOP subcommittees, such
as the Social Committee and Union
Board, to name a few.
The vice-president, then, should be
chosen with care because he directly influences student life on campus. And,
if there's one thing that irks us, it's
listening to the endless prattling of those
who complain about people who are appointed to these positions. Constantly
heard on campus are such choice
remarks as "They get the same people
every year for these jobs," or "That
loser!?!" While granted, selections rely in large part upon the quality of the
applicant pool, the direction of the chair
of the selection committee can also play
a pivotal role in choosing satisfactory
and appropriate candidates.
If you can manage, then, to get to the
MSE on Tuesday, we would encourage
you (especially the more vocally critical
of you)to cast informed votes—not only for vice-president, but for Young
Trustee as well. Candidate statements
will be available at voting sites; it will
be worth your while to riffle through
them.

Find natural food at Belly Co-op
by Lisa Goldberg
Walk in The Belly and you're likely to be greeted with
a smile. This Waverly food vendor is Baltimore's only
natural food storefront co-op, and its members are seriously committed to providing good food to the local
community.
The Belly is not run for profit; if it did turn a profit,
the proceeds, as member Mark Snesil noted, "would have
to be given away." Food bought on sale is sold on sale,
and prices may not rise until weeks after inflation has hit.
Gussie Tweedy, a four-year member of The Belly, recalled selling bagels for six weeks below cost.
All the food at The Belly is vegetarian, although
Tweedy admitted to sometimes sneaking in salmon or
tuna. The selection filled food and flours is extensive,
ranging from pe,arleu parley, kasha and organic buckwheat
flour to organic black turtle beans and lentils. Organic,
explained Tweedy, actually does mean more than high
prices: certified organic food must be grown in soil not

fertilized by chemicals in two years. Distributors•are
responding to the increased demand for chemical-free
food; as their organic stock increases, prices may drop
accordingly.
Fruits and vegetables at The Belly are more mundane:
apples, onions, and potatoes are standard stock. Canned
and jarred foods are sparse and highly-priced: a 25 oz.
jar of sugar-free applesauce cost $1.72, in comparison
with $.89 at Eddie's. The breads, some with flavorings as
exotic as cheddar cheese or peach, are delivered fresh

Ely Brown

Ely Brown

Tuesdays and Fridays. The spice collection is extensive
and well-priced. Most dried foods and spices are sold by
weight.
Anyone can shop at The Belly, but membership provides up to a 15 percent discount. Individuals can become
members by paying $15 and, if they choose, by working
a minimum of three hours per month at the store.
Members can also work at The Belly without paying a
fee. The Belly currently claims approximately one hundred members; approximately twenty members are
Hopkins students. New members, said Snesil, are

welcome, "not just from the consumer end but as an active voice as to what the store can be for everyone. We
have lots of room to grow." New members join the coop by attending one of Snesil's biweekly orientation
meetings; signup sheets are posted in the store.
The Belly was founded in 1975 by students as a means
to provide cheaper food, without the cost of paid labor.
Lack of storage space prevents the co-op from buying food
at bulk rates, but food is always sold at the lowest possible prices. Members work when they want to; consequently, the atmosphere is caring and relaxed. As Tweedy
noted, "We provide an essential service. . .everybody
needs food."
For variety and freshness in dried foods, flours, and
spices, The Belly can't be beat, although I would recommend shopping elsewhere for canned goods and produce.

Undergraduate Reading Series offers
\students an easy and enjoyable way to learn
by Richard Anderson
Perhaps by now even some of the most driven of you:
Hopkins students have begun to tire of the endless grind
of homework assignments, books to read, and papers to
write. Perhaps some of you have begun to wonder why
in the world you are still here, or even why you came
in the first place. Isn't there some less painful way, you
wonder, for a student to acquire useful information on
his or her way to becoming a contributing member of
society? Unfortunately, the simple, distressing fact is that
most classes here at Hopkins are designed to force the
required material into the heads of us unwilling victims
with the maximum amount of pain possible.
Fortunately, there do exist alternative methods of learning, methods that don't necessarily require that one submit to the rigors of the classroom. I have recently become
acquainted with one such alternative. It is the
Undergraduate Reading, sponsored by the Writing
Seminars Department.
Every Monday night at about six or seven-thirty, a
group of people meet in the Little Theatre in Levering
Hall to listen to various students read their prose and
poetry aloud. The program is co-chaired by two
undergraduates, Jenny Levy and Louise Redd, both
Writing Seminars majors. I had the opportunity to talk
to both of them and to attend the two most recent programs of the series.
The programs were started about ten years ago by the
late Dr. Robert Arellano, who was concerned about providing an opportunity for students to receive criticism on
their writing from peers outside of the classroom environment. Since then it has been sponsored by various pro-

fessors in the Writing Seminars department up until the
current sponsor, Jean McGarry, who was previously a
graduate student in the department. Both Redd and Levy
commented that the interest that McGarry has shown has
been very encouraging.
Redd stressed that any undergraduate who felt the desire
to read was welcome to do so, and also expressed the
desire that the attendance to the programs was larger and
more consistent. Anyone who wants to read can contact
one of the co-chairs as little as a week in advance of the
desired reading date and still be assured of consideration.
At both programs I attended, I was particularly struck
by the relaxed atmosphere. Nobody seemed conscious of
the passage of time, and a few minutes stretched easily
and unnoticeably into five or ten. During the break, people wandered into little groups talking and laughing, or
just lounged on the chairs, smoking cigarettes. Over in
one corner, a girl started to bang on the piano, while in
another, two guys discussed going out for a drink
afterwards.
The stories and poems were interesting and absorbing,
dealing with subjects as varied as the people who read
them were different. A junior philosophy major read a
number of her poems on African and Asian love themes,
while a senior football player read a story about a downon-his-luck private eye. Another senior, like the football
player in the writing seminars department, read some witty letters written to him by a friend, as well as an excellent
story about a journalist going through significant changes
in his life. There was a story about the sweetness of
revenge, and a particularly humorous one concerning an
analysis of the various methods of vomiting.
But back to the central problem: the ability of a stu-

of the selection committee can also play
a pivotal role in choosing satisfactory
and appropriate candidates.

you (especially the more vocally critical
of you)to cast informed votes—not only for vice-president, but for Young

be worth your while to riffle through

Find natural food at Belly Co-op
by Lisa Goldberg
Walk in The Belly and you're likely to be greeted with
a smile. This Waverly food vendor is Baltimore's only
natural food storefront co-op, and its members are seriously committed to providing good food to the local
community.
The Belly is not run for profit; if it did turn a profit,
the proceeds, as member Mark Snesil noted, "would have
to be given away." Food bought on sale is sold on sale,
and prices may not rise until weeks after inflation has hit.
Gussie Tweedy, a four-year member of The Belly, recalled selling bagels for six weeks below cost.
All the food at The Belly is vegetarian, although
Tweedy admitted to sometimes sneaking in salmon or
tuna. The selection filled food and flours is extensive,
ranging from pe,arleu parley, kasha and organic buckwheat
flour to organic black turtle beans and lentils. Organic,
explained Tweedy, actually does mean more than high
prices: certified organic food must be grown in soil not

fertilized by chemicals in two years. Distributors•are
responding to the increased demand for chemical-free
food; as their organic stock increases, prices may drop
accordingly.
Fruits and vegetables at The Belly are more mundane:
apples, onions, and potatoes are standard stock. Canned
and jarred foods are sparse and highly-priced: a 25 oz.
jar of sugar-free applesauce cost $1.72, in comparison
with $.89 at Eddie's. The breads, some with flavorings as
exotic as cheddar cheese or peach, are delivered fresh

Undergraduate Reading Series offers
\students an easy and enjoyable way to learn
by Richard Anderson
Perhaps by now even some of the most driven of you:
Hopkins students have begun to tire of the endless grind
of homework assignments, books to read, and papers to
write. Perhaps some of you have begun to wonder why
in the world you are still here, or even why you came
in the first place. Isn't there some less painful way, you
wonder, for a student to acquire useful information on
his or her way to becoming a contributing member of
society? Unfortunately, the simple, distressing fact is that
most classes here at Hopkins are designed to force the
required material into the heads of us unwilling victims
with the maximum amount of pain possible.
Fortunately, there do exist alternative methods of learning, methods that don't necessarily require that one submit to the rigors of the classroom. I have recently become
acquainted with one such alternative. It is the
Undergraduate Reading, sponsored by the Writing
Seminars Department.
Every Monday night at about six or seven-thirty, a
group of people meet in the Little Theatre in Levering
Hall to listen to various students read their prose and
poetry aloud. The program is co-chaired by two
undergraduates, Jenny Levy and Louise Redd, both
Writing Seminars majors. I had the opportunity to talk
to both of them and to attend the two most recent programs of the series.
The programs were started about ten years ago by the
late Dr. Robert Arellano, who was concerned about providing an opportunity for students to receive criticism on
their writing from peers outside of the classroom environment. Since then it has been sponsored by various pro-

fessors in the Writing Seminars department up until the
current sponsor, Jean McGarry, who was previously a
graduate student in the department. Both Redd and Levy
commented that the interest that McGarry has shown has
been very encouraging.
Redd stressed that any undergraduate who felt the desire
to read was welcome to do so, and also expressed the
desire that the attendance to the programs was larger and
more consistent. Anyone who wants to read can contact
one of the co-chairs as little as a week in advance of the
desired reading date and still be assured of consideration.
At both programs I attended, I was particularly struck
by the relaxed atmosphere. Nobody seemed conscious of
the passage of time, and a few minutes stretched easily
and unnoticeably into five or ten. During the break, people wandered into little groups talking and laughing, or
just lounged on the chairs, smoking cigarettes. Over in
one corner, a girl started to bang on the piano, while in
another, two guys discussed going out for a drink
afterwards.
The stories and poems were interesting and absorbing,
dealing with subjects as varied as the people who read
them were different. A junior philosophy major read a
number of her poems on African and Asian love themes,
while a senior football player read a story about a downon-his-luck private eye. Another senior, like the football
player in the writing seminars department, read some witty letters written to him by a friend, as well as an excellent
story about a journalist going through significant changes
in his life. There was a story about the sweetness of
revenge, and a particularly humorous one concerning an
analysis of the various methods of vomiting.
But back to the central problem: the ability of a stu-

by Aaron Goldenberg
The men's and women's
basketball teams have achieved
several milestones this past year.
For the women, it was their first
winning season ever. For the
men, it was a tie for the most wins
in Hopkins history (17), the MAC
Southeastern Division Championship, and a fifth place ranking in
the Middle Athletic region (one
spot shy of being invited to the
national tournament). However,
it has not always been this way.
Three years ago, when coaches
Bill Nelson and Nancy Blank arrived at Hopkins, the basketball
programs were looking for focus
and direction. There was virtually no effort made to recruit and
bring in substantial scholar
athletes and create a winning atmosphere at Hopkins. Nelson and
Blank were hired in June of 1986
to do just that.
Robert Scott, Director of
Athletics at Hopkins, described
coaches Nelson and Blank as
"proven coaches with proven
records." That they certainly are.
In 1986, Nelson came to Hopkins
having spent three years at
Nazareth College in Rochester
and three years at Rochester Institute of Technology. He has
been honored as Coach of the
Year by the Independent Collegiate Athletic Conference and
the New York State Basketball
Coaches Association, and has
reached the NCAA Division III
Tournament twice. At R.I.T., he
transformed a very lackluster

program into a conference champion in three years. Sound
familiar? His final year at
Nazareth, he finished second in
the New York State Coaches Poll
and seventh in the Final NCAA
Division III poll.
Blank also came to Hopkins
after guiding Messiah College to
the W.C.I.A. Championship in
1978 and 1980 and the NCAA
District II Championship in 1982
and 1983.
The main reason, however,
that Nelson and Blank have been
able to achieve such tremendous
success, besides their ability to
coach the sport well, is their ability to recruit excellent scholarathletes. According to Jerome
Schnydman, Director of
Undergraduate Admissions,
"There are two reasons why
coaches are successful. One,
because they can coach the sport.
The second is because they are
good recruiters, which is one of
the reasons why they have had the
ability to be good coaches. From
the start, they have been successful in identifying studentathletes who might be interested
in Hopkins. When I ask them
about the people they recruit,
...they know all about them,
academically and athletically. . .The proof is in the pudding,
they are doing well in school and
on the court. What they have said
has proven true, they have done
the job recruiting good students
who are good athletes."
Even though Hopkins has committed itself to improving its

basketball programs, it has not
been forced to compromise admissions standards to do so. In
fact, the story is quite the opposite. According to Nelson, his
basketball team is a composite of
not only both social and physical
science majors, but claims a
former high school valedictorian
and a Beneficial Hodson Scholar.
According to Blank, recruiting
has been extremely instrumental
to her teams success. In her attempts to recruit a freshman
class, she, like Nelson, visits
players throughout the year, visits
basketball camps during the summer, and uses a recruiting
statistical service (called Metro
Index) to sort through the endless
list of potential prospects. Also
through her network of contacts,
she will try to get a feel for those
scholar-athletes who might be interested in playing Division III
basketball at a school like
Hopkins.
The first step for Blank is to go
through her list of potential prospects and sort out those whom
she feels are academically
qualified because, according to
her, "there is no use wasting your
time on a kid who can't get in the
front door." Then she starts contacting prospects and keeps contacting them until she feels they
may no longer have an interest in
attending the school. Once she
has narrowed this list down further, she goes and sees potential
prospects play several times or
watches videotapes of games. In
this process, she tries not to limit

herself to merely the northeast
and covers as much of the country as possible. Once she has seen
her recruits, she, like Nelson and
other coaches, drafts a ranked list
of her recruited applicants and
then waits and hopes they are
admitted.
For Nelson, the process is
much the same. Also relying on
sources such as Metro Index,
visiting summer camps, personal
contacts, and responding to student inquiries, Nelson sends out
over 200 questionairres contacting prospective student-athletes.
'About one quarter of those return

those dozen players, Nelson tries
to watch as many as possible
play. Of the rest, he and his staff

Nelson, he will have seen next

this year.
Nelson does not mass recruit,

is currently on track to be
